Context.text: The first clause of the Mishnah is discussing whether a man can halachically engage a woman via a messenger without himself being present. Do you think this would work? Why or why not?

Basic explanation.text: The word מקדש ("mekadesh") means "making something holy," usually used in the context of a man creating the legal status of "kiddushin" with a woman prior to marriage, but also, for example, Hashem being

Advanced explanation.text: For those interested in grammar, the word מקדש is the
the _pi'el_ participle of the shoresh קדש

Parts of speech.text: The word מקדש can function as a noun, meaning "someone who makes something holy", a verb, someone or something "is making holy," or an adjective, something has "the quality of making something holy."

What does \"being mekadesh\" mean here?.text: We find here a klal of mishnayos that a "present tense" statement means a psak, and so "the man is being mekadesh himself or with an emissary" in this context means "the man is
to be mekadesh, himself or with an emissary."

Why does it say the man?.text: If the Mishnah wanted to say "any man can be mekadesh an isha using these methods," why did it say "
man can be mekadesh", as if only some specific man can do it, instead of saying "
man can be mekadesh," ie any man? (Then it would read: איש מקדש, instead of האיש מקדש, because

Why does it say the man?.enclosingTopic: First clause of the Mishnah on Kiddushin 41a
Why does it say the man?.enclosingSubtopic: Why does it say the man?
